facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948,

facts.text: Appeal arose from Nagpur High Court judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948 in First Appeal No. 27 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 7, 1948, of the Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 27 of 1954 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 7, 1944,

facts.text: Nagpur High Court appeal originated from Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur judgment dated July 7, 1944 in Civil Suit No. 10-B of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: of the Nagpur High Court in First Appeal No. 27 of 1954 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 7, 1944, of the Court of Third Additional District Judge, Nagpur, in Civil Suit No. 10-B of 1943.

facts.text: Appellants owned two motor trucks: No. AWB 230 V-8 Ford 1938 Model and No. AWB 253 Oldsmobile Model 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants carried on business in partnership in the firm name and style of Ishwarsing Dhiansingh and were the owners of two motor trucks, one bearing No. AWB 230  V-8 Ford 1938 Model  and the other bearing No. AWB 253  Oldsmobile Model 1938 .

facts.text: On May 4, 1942, appellants entered into hiring agreement with respondent for the trucks at Rs. 17 per day per truck, terminable on one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: On May 4, 1942, the appellants entered into an agreement for the hiring out of these trucks to the respondent for imparting tuition to the military personnel. Rupees 17 per day per truck was stipulated as the hire and the agreement was terminable on one months numberice by either side.

facts.text: Truck No. AWB 230 handed over to respondent on April 29, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the said agreement truck No. AWB 230 was handed over to the respondent on April 29, 1942, and truck No. AWB 253 was given on May 4, 1942.

facts.text: Truck No. AWB 253 handed over to respondent on May 4, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the said agreement truck No. AWB 230 was handed over to the respondent on April 29, 1942, and truck No. AWB 253 was given on May 4, 1942.

facts.text: Respondent used truck AWB 230 from April 29, 1942 to July 31, 1942, except June 4 to June 9, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent used truck No. AWB 230 from April 29, 1942, to July 31, 1942, excepting the period from June 4, 1942, to June 9, 1942,

facts.text: Respondent used truck AWB 253 from May 4, 1942 to July 31, 1942, except June 1 to June 9, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: and truck No. AWB 253 from May 4, 1942, to July 31, 1942, excepting the period from June 1, 1942, to June 9, 1942.

facts.text: On June 29, 1942, respondent gave notice terminating agreement effective August 1, 1942, and asked appellants to remove trucks.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1942, the respondent gave numberice to the appellants terminating the agreement with effect from August 1, 1942, and asked them to remove the trucks on the expiration of that period.

facts.text: On August 1, 1942 at 9 a.m., Appellant No. 1 attended Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee to remove trucks but not delivered.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 1 attended upon the Officer Commanding 4 T.T. Centre, Kamptee at about 9 a.m. on August 1, 1942, for removing the trucks but they were number delivered to him by the transport in-charge

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 wrote letter on August 1, 1942 to S.S.O., Kamptee recording non-delivery.

anchor.surface_text: and by his letter of the same date addressed to the S. S.O., Kamptee, the appellant No. 1 put the above fact on record.

facts.text: Respondent did not return trucks nor pay hire charges.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number return the trucks to the Appellants number did it pay any hire charges to them.

facts.text: Respondent claimed hire paid and trucks delivered to Surjan Singh, alleged partner of appellants. (Disputed by appellants)

anchor.surface_text: The respondent took up the position that the amount of hire had been paid and the trucks had been delivered by it to one Surjan Singh who was alleged to have been a partner of the appellants and thus entitled to receive the said payment and the delivery of the trucks in question.

facts.text: Trial Court held respondent not justified in paying rent and delivering trucks to Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the respondent was number justified in paying the rent and delivering the trucks to the said Surjan Singh.

facts.text: Suit filed by appellants on January 8, 1943 against respondent and Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: with the result that on January 8, 1943, the appellants filed a suit against the respondent and the said Surjan Singh claiming the aforesaid reliefs

facts.text: Notice under s.80 CPC given by appellants on August 4, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: On August 4, 1942, the appellants gave the requisite numberice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure to the respondent

facts.text: Trial Court decreed Rs. 6,032-4-0 with costs against respondent and Surjan Singh on July 7, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: It accordingly passed a decree in favour of the appellant for Rs. 6,032-4-0 with proportionate companyts against the respondent as well as Surjan Singh.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Nagpur High Court, valued appeal at Rs. 5,953 initially.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred an appeal to the High Court of Judicature at Nagpur. They claimed a total sum of Rs. 11,985 as also the highest market value of the trucks.

facts.text: High Court on February 19, 1945 ordered additional court-fee on Rs.16,626, paid February 28, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The Office of the Registrar took objection to the amount of that companyrt-fee and on February 19, 1945, a Bench of the High Court passed an order that the appellants must pay companyrt-fee on Rs. 16,626

facts.text: High Court heard appeal on April 1, 1948, enhanced decree by Rs. 5,953.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court On April 1, 1948. The High Court disallowed the appellants claim for the higher value of the trucks

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 29, 1957 by Bhagwati J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. October 29. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with a certificate of fitness under s. 110

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellants entitled to value of trucks at Rs.7,000 as at date of judgment.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the appellants were entitled to recover from the respondent the value of the said trucks which, as has been already stated, was Rs. 7,000 in the alternative,

facts.text: Supreme Court awarded additional damages of Rs.6,457 for wrongful detention.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants would therefore be entitled to recover over and above the sum of Rs. 5,953 already awarded to them by the High Court an additional sum of Rs. 6,457 by way of damages

facts.text: Rent calculated at Rs.2,380 up to July 31, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The rent of the trucks was calculated at Rs. 2,380 and it awarded to the appellant that sum together with interest thereon at 6 per annum from August 1, 1942,

issues.text: raises an important question as to the rights and remedies of a bailor in the event of non-delivery of the goods by the bailee

anchor.surface_text: This appeal with a certificate of fitness under s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure raises an important question as to the rights and remedies of a bailor in the event of non-delivery of the goods by the bailee.

issues.text: whether the appellants suit was one for wrongful detention and the appellants were entitled to return of the two trucks or in the alternative to the value thereof as on the date of the decree

anchor.surface_text: that the appellants suit was one for wrongful detention and the appellants were entitled to return of the two trucks or in the alternative to the value thereof as on the date of the decree, that the value of the two trucks at the date of the decree was Rs. 7,000 each

issues.text: that in addition to the above relief the appellants were entitled to damages for wrongful detention of the trucks calculated at the rate of Rs. 17 per day per truck from August 1, 1942 ... till ... the date of the decree

anchor.surface_text: that in addition to the above relief the appellants were entitled to damages for wrongful detention of the trucks calculated at the rate of Rs. 17 per day per truck from August 1, 1942, being the date of the accrual of the cause of action till July 7, 1944, which was the date of the decree passed by the Trial Court in their favour.

issues.text: at its worst the respondent was ... guilty of wrongful conversion ... only entitled to damages for wrongful conversion which are commensurate with the price of the trucks at the date of such wrongful conversion

anchor.surface_text: that at its worst the respondent was to the knowledge of the appellant guilty of wrongful conversion of the said trucks from August 1, 1942, and that the appellants were only entitled to damages for wrongful conversion which are commensurate with the price of the trucks at the date of such wrongful conversion

issues.text: a bailor in the event of the non-delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him in that behalf is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or for the wrongful detention thereof

anchor.surface_text: a bailor in the event of the non-delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him in that behalf is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or the wrongful detention thereof and if the bailor pursues his remedy against the bailee for wrongful detention of the goods it would be no answer for the bailee to say that he was guilty of wrongful conversion

issues.text: What is the amount which the appellants are entitled to recover from the respondent as and by way of the value of the two trucks in the alternative-the respondent being admittedly not in a position to re-deliver the said trucks to them

issues.text: what are the damages which the appellants are entitled to recover by reason of wrongful detention of the trucks till the date of judgment

anchor.surface_text: 2 what are the damages which the appellants are entitled to recover by reason of wrongful detention of the trucks till the date of judgment.

issues.text: whether the appellants were entitled to the value of the said trucks in the alternative as at the date of the judgment or at the date of the tort, whether it be conversion or wrongful detention

anchor.surface_text: Turning then to the question whether the appellants were entitled to the value of the said trucks in the alternative as at the date of the judgment or at the date of the tort, whether it be conversion or wrongful detention, the position appears to be a little confused.

arguments.court_reasoning: Error to limit by court-fee; calculate reasonable use period at hire rate (approx 1 year, Rs.12,410).

arguments.claim: Bailor entitled at election to sue for wrongful conversion or detention; bailee cannot plead own prior conversion as answer to detinue.

anchor.surface_text: a bailor in the event of the non-delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him in that behalf is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or the wrongful detention thereof

arguments.claim: s.80 notice complied with; claiming value at notice date (Rs.3,500) suffices for suit claiming value at decree date; common sense construction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disallowed the appellants claim for the higher value of the trucks on the ground that the appellants had merely claimed Rs. 3,500 as the price of the said trucks in the notice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure

arguments.claim: In detinue (wrongful detention), value assessed at date of judgment/verdict, not tort date; continuing wrong until delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Turning then to the question whether the appellants were entitled to the value of the said trucks in the alternative as at the date of the judgment or at the date of the tort, whether it be conversion or wrongful detention

arguments.claim: Damages for wrongful detention: reasonable hire rate (Rs.17/day/truck) for reasonable use period, even without proof of actual loss/hirer.
Bailee cannot take advantage of own wrong (prior conversion) to force conversion remedy on bailor.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant cannot be heard to say that the plaintiff knew or ought to have known of the conversion. He cannot take advantage of his own wrong.

arguments.claim: No undue delay by appellants; elected detinue promptly after demand.

anchor.surface_text: There was no delay on the part of the appellants which would spell out any intention on their part to take advantage of the rising market

arguments.claim: Evidence sufficient for Rs.7,000 value at decree date (100% appreciation).

anchor.surface_text: The evidence however was sufficient to enable the Trial Court to come to the conclusion that the price of the said two trucks which had been fixed at Rs. 3,500

holdings.text: A bailor in the event of the non-delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or for wrongful detention thereof; bailee cannot plead own prior conversion as defence to detinue.

anchor.surface_text: a bailor in the event of the non-delivery of the goods by the bailee on a demand made by him in that behalf is entitled at his election to sue the bailee either for wrongful conversion of the goods or the wrongful detention thereof and if the bailor pursues his remedy against the bailee for wrongful detention of the goods it would be no answer for the bailee to say that he was guilty of wrongful conversion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies settled law from Reeve v. Palmer (1858), Wilkinson v. Verity (1871), Rosenthal, Goulding; wrongdoer cannot take advantage of own wrong; election belongs to bailor.

holdings.text: The appellants' suit is properly one for wrongful detention (detinue), not conversion, as they elected specific delivery despite knowledge of delivery to Surjan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: There was no delay on the part of the appellants which would spell out any intention on their part to take advantage of the rising market or to waive their remedy in wrongful conversion with a view to take advantage of the statute of limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prompt demand on Aug 1, 1942, notice Aug 4 seeking delivery, suit Jan 8, 1943; no evidence of waiver or delay to speculate on market.

holdings.text: Notice under s.80 CPC claiming value at date of breach (Rs.3,500) complies strictly; suffices for suit claiming alternative value at date of decree due to appreciation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disallowed the appellants claim for the higher value of the trucks on the ground that the appellants had merely claimed Rs. 3,500 as the price of the said trucks in the notice under s. 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure and that they were therefore not entitled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict compliance but common sense, not pedantic; cites Bhagchand (PC), Jones v Nicholls, Chandu Lal; notice substance clear for re-delivery or then-value; future appreciation unforeseeable.

holdings.text: In action for wrongful detention (detinue), alternative value of goods assessed at date of judgment/verdict, as continuing tort until delivery; distinct from conversion (tort date).

anchor.surface_text: Turning then to the question whether the appellants were entitled to the value of the said trucks in the alternative as at the date of the judgment or at the date of the tort, whether it be conversion or wrongful detention, the position appears to be a little confused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Rosenthal v Alderton (CA 1946) over prior conversion cases; plaintiff retains title, continuing wrong; Winfield on Tort; distinguishes S.S. Celia (fixed loss).

holdings.text: Appellants entitled to value of trucks at Rs.7,000 (as at judgment date) in alternative to return.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the appellants were entitled to recover from the respondent the value of the said trucks which, as has been already stated, was Rs. 7,000 in the alternative,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence sufficient for 100% appreciation from Rs.3,500; Trial Court erred applying tort-date rule; High Court erred on s.80.

holdings.text: Damages for wrongful detention measured at reasonable hire rate (Rs.17/day/truck) for reasonable user period (~1 year here, total Rs.12,410), even without proof of actual hirer/loss.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to mesne profits; wrongdoer pays fair rental (Strand Electric, Denning LJ); appellants' hiring business; reasonable allowance for idle days; High Court erred limiting by court-fee.

holdings.text: Appellants entitled to additional Rs.6,457 damages beyond High Court award, plus Rs.3,500 appreciated value, interest, costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above rules to facts; total value Rs.7,000, detention Rs.12,410.

justification_sets.label: Measure of Damages in Detinue support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow this appeal and pass in favour of the appellants, in addition to the enhanced decree which they have already obtained from the High Court, a decree against the respondent for Rs. 3,500 being the appreciated value of the said trucks together with interest thereon at 6 per annum from July 7, 1944, till this date as also for a sum of Rs. 6,457 by way of additional damages for wrongful detention of the said trucks, add

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed. Decree for Rs. 3,500 (appreciated value of trucks) with interest at 6% p.a. from July 7, 1944 till judgment date; Rs. 6,457 additional damages for wrongful detention; additional proportionate costs in Trial Court and High Court; costs of this appeal.
